====Royal tour==== [[File:2012 Royal Tour of Canada, Queen's Park 7.JPG|thumb|left|[[Charles, Prince of Wales]], speaks to the public outside of the [[Ontario Legislative Building]] during his tour of Canada for the Diamond Jubilee]]
[[Charles, Prince of Wales]], and [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]], toured parts of the country in May,<ref name=CNW/> making stops in [[New Brunswick]], Ontario, and [[Saskatchewan]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14382| last=Office of the Governor General of Canada| title=Their Royal Highnesses The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall to Undertake a Royal Tour of Canada in 2012| date=14 December 2011| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=14 December 2011| deadurl=no| archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20141014105320/http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14382| archivedate=14 October 2014| df=dmy-all}}</ref> In an editorial he wrote for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', Charles stated he wanted his activities during the tour to reflect the jubilee's "central theme of service to others" and expressed that he was "returning to Canada in this special Jubilee year, to renew my own pledge of service and to encourage others to consider how they might contribute their own particular talent".<ref>{{citation| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/opinion/through-service-to-others-we-build-strong-communities/article2436190/| author1=Prince Charles| author2=Prince of Wales| authorlink=Charles, Prince of Wales| title=Through service to others, we build strong communities| date=18 May 2012| newspaper=The Globe and Mail| accessdate=25 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523202145/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/opinion/through-service-to-others-we-build-strong-communities/article2436190/| archivedate=23 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> In that vein, he in all three provinces visited with people associated with his organisation [[The Prince's Charities#The Prince's Charities Canada|The Prince's Charities Canada]] and presented Diamond Jubilee Medals to recipients.
The couple arrived at [[Saint John Airport]] on the evening of 20 May.<ref name=DCHItinerary>{{cite web| url=http://pch.gc.ca/eng/1336669990111/1336670644633| last=Department of Canadian Heritage| title=Topics > Monarchy in Canada > 2012 Royal Tour > 2012 Royal Tour Itinerary| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=11 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521034454/http://pch.gc.ca/eng/1336669990111/1336670644633| archivedate=21 May 2014| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The following day, they were formally welcomed by the Governor General and met at [[CFB Gagetown|Canadian Forces Base Gagetown]] with young Canadian Forces veterans and mentors involved in the Military Entrepreneurship program before moving on to [[Saint John, New Brunswick|Saint John]]. There, they undertook a walking tour of Prince William Street to observe heritage projects and meet the 2002 Committee for the Prince of Wales Municipal Heritage Leadership Prize, participated in a citizenship ceremony, attended [[Victoria Day]] events, and opened the Diamond Jubilee IT Centre at Hazen-White-St. Francis School.<ref name=DCHItinerary/> They then flew on to [[Toronto]] to meet with emergency workers and their families and observe the annual fireworks show at [[The Beaches|Ashbridges Bay]] that marks Victoria Day and the [[Queen's Birthday#Canada|Queen's official Canadian birthday]]. [[File:Saskatchewan legislative building.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Saskatchewan Legislative Building]], the centenary of which was marked by [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], and [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]], as part of their Canadian Queen's Diamond Jubilee tour]]
On 22 May, the couple attended an event hosted by the Lieutenant Governor of Ontario at [[Queen's Park (Toronto)|Queen's Park]]. After, the Duchess visited [[The Queen's Own Rifles of Canada]], of which she is colonel-in-chief,<ref>{{citation| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/article/1170776--royal-tour-2012-details-announced-for-charles-and-camilla-s-tour-of-toronto| last=Daubs| first=Katie| title=Royal Tour 2012: Details announced for Charles and Camilla's tour of Toronto| date=30 April 2012| newspaper=Toronto Star| accessdate=5 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120827070741/http://www.thestar.com/news/article/1170776--royal-tour-2012-details-announced-for-charles-and-camilla-s-tour-of-toronto| archivedate=27 August 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> laying at the armoury a wreath in memory of fallen Canadian soldiers, while the Prince of Wales saw the Digital Media Zone at [[Ryerson University]], toured the construction site of the athletes' village for the [[2015 Pan American Games]] (where [[Premier of Ontario]] [[Dalton McGuinty]] announced a portion of [[Front Street (Toronto)|Front Street]] running through the village would be named ''Diamond Jubilee Promenade''<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120522/prince-charles-camilla-in-toronto-120522/#ixzz1vhjnJQPS| title=Prince Charles, Camilla head to Regina after Toronto tour| date=22 May 2012| publisher=CTV| accessdate=23 May 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525075702/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120522/prince-charles-camilla-in-toronto-120522#ixzz1vhjnJQPS| archivedate=25 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>), visited the Yonge Street Mission, and met with the national leadership of the [[Assembly of First Nations]]. The couple also attended a luncheon hosted by the [[government of Ontario]] and participated in a [[Canadian Forces]] event at [[Fort York]] commemorating the 200th anniversary of the [[War of 1812]],<ref name=DCHItinerary /> the Prince there wearing his uniform of a [[Lieutenant-general (Canada)|lieutenant-general]] of the [[Canadian Army]].
They arrived in [[Regina, Saskatchewan|Regina]] on 23 May and marked the centenary of [[Saskatchewan Legislative Building|Saskatchewan's legislative building]], participated in a reception held by the Lieutenant Governor of Saskatchewan at Government House, toured the [[First Nations University of Canada]], and visited an environmentally friendly water purification plant. In the evening, the Prince and Duchess attended at the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) Depot Division Drill Hall a performance of the [[Regina Symphony Orchestra]], of which Prince Charles is patron.<ref name=DCHItinerary/><ref>{{cite web| url=http://pch.gc.ca/eng/1335470669033/1335471159074| last=Department of Canadian Heritage| title=The Department > Newsroom > Government of Canada Unveils Details of the 2012 Royal Tour| date=30 April 2012| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=5 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130628032051/http://www.pch.gc.ca/eng/1335470669033/1335471159074| archivedate=28 June 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref> There, the Prime Minister announced that Charles was to be appointed Honorary Commissioner of the RCMP, taking the post from his mother, the Queen, who became the RCMP's Commissioner-in-Chief.<ref>{{citation| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/harper-names-prince-charles-honorary-rcmp-commissioner/article2441944/| last=Mackrael| first=Kim| title=Harper names Prince Charles honorary RCMP commissioner| date=23 May 2012| newspaper=The Globe and Mail| accessdate=25 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526020840/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/harper-names-prince-charles-honorary-rcmp-commissioner/article2441944/| archivedate=26 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[New Democratic Party of Canada|New Democratic Party]] MP [[Pat Martin]], an open anti-monarchist, stated in the [[House of Commons of Canada|House of Commons]] that the tour was "a [[Bread and circuses|bread-and-circuses]] routine" intended to distract from cuts to the [[Public Service of Canada|federal civil service]].<ref>{{citation| url=http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/04/30/kelly-mcparland-nathan-cullens-deportment-police-can-start-with-pat-martin/| last=McParland| first=Kelly| title=Nathan Cullen's deportment police can start with Pat Martin| date=30 April 2012| newspaper=National Post| accessdate=6 May 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120716091322/http://fullcomment.nationalpost.com/2012/04/30/kelly-mcparland-nathan-cullens-deportment-police-can-start-with-pat-martin/| archivedate=16 July 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Minister of Canadian Heritage, [[James Moore (Canadian politician)|James Moore]], said the tour would be the "least expensive for taxpayers" of those that had taken place since 2009.<ref>{{citation| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawa-notebook/tories-blasted-over-1-million-bread-and-circuses-royal-tour/article2417917/?from=sec501| last=Chase| first=Steven| title=Tories blasted over $1-million 'bread and circuses' royal tour| date=30 April 2012| newspaper=The Globe and Mail| accessdate=6 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525182454/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawa-notebook/tories-blasted-over-1-million-bread-and-circuses-royal-tour/article2417917/?from=sec501| archivedate=25 May 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Events through June==== At the Queen's request,<ref name=CTVRCMP>{{cite news |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20120523/rcmp-musical-ride-buckingham-palace-guard-duty-120523/ |title=Mounties guard the Queen in London for a day |date=23 May 2012 |publisher=CTV |accessdate=25 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525075532/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/TopStories/20120523/rcmp-musical-ride-buckingham-palace-guard-duty-120523/ |archivedate=25 May 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> members of the RCMP's [[Musical Ride]], after performing in the [[Diamond Jubilee Pageant]] at [[Windsor Castle]], took part in the Changing of the Guard on 23 May as they formed the [[Queen's Guard|Queen's Life Guard]] outside Buckingham Palace for 24 hours.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iUQJHXQFYW2HsFHhH0wdTWl5oEsw?docId=CNG.da5623a1e1f2af30fd41b88f6c00592c.301| title=Canada's Mounties guard Buckingham Palace| date=24 May 2012|agency=AFP| accessdate=25 May 2012}}</ref> Said by the contingent's commander to be a "way for Canada and the Mounties to salute her Majesty the Queen in her Diamond Jubilee year",<ref name=CTVRCMP/> it was the second time the RCMP had performed the task since doing so as a part of the Diamond Jubilee celebrations for Queen Victoria in 1897.<ref>{{citation| url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/worldview/mounties-set-to-replace-queens-life-guard-at-buckingham-palace-for-one-day/article2439909/| last=Saunders| first=Doug| title=Mounties set to replace Queen's Life Guard at Buckingham Palace for one day| date=22 May 2012| newspaper=The Globe and Mail| accessdate=25 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525115523/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/worldview/mounties-set-to-replace-queens-life-guard-at-buckingham-palace-for-one-day/article2439909/| archivedate=25 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> {{Quote box| width=250px| border=1px| align=left| quote=We, Your Majesty's loyal and dutiful subjects, the House of Commons of Canada in Parliament assembled, beg to offer our sincere congratulations on the happy completion of the sixtieth year of Your reign.
In this, the Diamond Jubilee year of your reign as Queen of Canada, we trust that Your gracious and peaceful reign may continue for many years and that Divine Providence will preserve Your Majesty in health, in happiness and in the affectionate loyalty of Your people.<ref name=LoyAddress>{{Citation| last=Parliament of Canada| year=2012| editor-last=O'Malley| editor-first=Kady| title=To The Queen's Most Excellent Majesty, with love from Her Canadian parliamentarians...| journal=CBC| publication-date=2012| url=http://www.cbc.ca/newsblogs/politics/inside-politics-blog/2012/06/to-the-queens-most-excellent-majesty-with-love-from-her-canadian-parliamentarians.html| accessdate=4 June 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727074637/http://www.cbc.ca/newsblogs/politics/inside-politics-blog/2012/06/to-the-queens-most-excellent-majesty-with-love-from-her-canadian-parliamentarians.html| archivedate=27 July 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref>| salign=right| source=Parliament of Canada, 2012}}
In the [[Parliament of Canada|federal parliament]] on 31 May, a loyal address to the Queen was passed.<ref name=LoyAddress /> The [[Lieutenant Governor of Manitoba]] held a Diamond Jubilee garden party at the province's Government House on 26 May.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120511/diamond-jubilee-events-schedule-itinerary-queen-120511/| title=The Diamond Jubilee: Schedule of events| date=14 May 2012| publisher=CTV| accessdate=28 May 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518082222/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20120511/diamond-jubilee-events-schedule-itinerary-queen-120511/| archivedate=18 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[Royal British Columbia Museum]] on 1 June opened an exhibition of approximately 100 [[Cecil Beaton]] photographs of Elizabeth II throughout her life.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalbcmuseum.bc.ca/Exhibit_Gall/queenelizabethII.aspx| title=Exhibits & Galleries > Visiting Exhibitions > Queen Elizabeth II by Cecil Beaton: A Diamond Jubilee Celebration| publisher=Royal British Columbia Museum| accessdate=2 March 2012}}{{dead link|date=August 2013}}</ref> [[File:Barbeau Peak, Nunavut.jpg|thumb|right|[[Barbeau Peak|Mount Barbeau]] in [[Nunavut]]]]
A team of Canadian and British mountaineers reached the summit of [[Barbeau Peak|Mount Barbeau]], in Canada's arctic, by 3 June and there held a tea party in celebration of the jubilee. From the summit, they sent a loyal greeting to the Queen via satellite, to which the monarch promised to reply.<ref>{{cite news| title=Adventurers to celebrate Queen’s Jubilee atop Arctic peak| date=22 May 2012| publisher=CBC}}</ref> The next day, a group from the [[Royal Canadian Dragoons]] stationed in [[Afghanistan]] climbed with British soldiers to the peak of the 7,000 foot mountain Gharib Ghar, within the [[Kabul Military Training Center]], "as part of the Diamond Jubilee celebrations for Queen Elizabeth II."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.dragoons.ca/afganchange.html| title=The Changing Role of Dragoons in Afghanistan| publisher=Royal Canadian Dragoons| accessdate=16 July 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721214108/http://www.dragoons.ca/afganchange.html| archivedate=21 July 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In the United Kingdom, [[Canada House]] held a Big Jubilee Lunch on 3 June and two beacons were lit on the building's roof the following evening,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/united_kingdom-royaume_uni/events-evenements/diamond_jubilee-jubile_diamant.aspx?lang=eng&view=d| last=High Commission of Canada to the United Kingdom| authorlink=High Commission of Canada to the United Kingdom| title=Canada celebrates Her Majesty's Diamond Jubilee| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=28 May 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505210732/http://www.canadainternational.gc.ca/united_kingdom-royaume_uni/events-evenements/diamond_jubilee-jubile_diamant.aspx?lang=eng&view=d| archivedate=5 May 2012 }}</ref> the night of the [[Diamond Jubilee Concert]]. Johnston attended both events and Harper was at the latter.<ref name=GGLondon /><ref name=VS>{{citation| url=http://www.vancouversun.com/entertainment/Harper+joins+Diamond+Jubilee+celebrations/6722925/story.html| last=Kennedy| first=Mark| title=Harper joins the Diamond Jubilee celebrations| date=3 June 2012| newspaper=Vancouver Sun| accessdate=4 June 2012}}{{dead link|date=August 2013}}</ref> Another reception was held at Canada House on the evening of 6 June, at which the Governor General and [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]], were present.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14560| last=Johnston| first=David| authorlink=David Johnston| title=Reception with the Business Community| date=6 June 2012| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=22 June 2012}}</ref> [[File:Rideau Hall 56.jpg|thumb|left|The portrait of Queen Elizabeth II painted to mark her Diamond Jubilee as Queen of Canada]]
Harper was granted an audience with the Queen at Buckingham Palace on 5 June.<ref name=VS/> Also at the palace, the Governor General, the Prime Minister, and the Queen unveiled a [[Canadian royal symbols#Artworks|new portrait of the sovereign]] commissioned by the federal Crown-in-Council and painted by Canadian painter Phil Richards. The creation of the portrait became the subject of a [[National Film Board of Canada]] (NFB) documentary directed by [[Hubert Davis (filmmaker)|Hubert Davis]] and released in the fall of 2012 as part of the NFB's ''Queen's Diamond Jubilee Collector's Edition''.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://realscreen.com/2012/06/07/national-film-board-puts-final-touches-to-the-portrait/#ixzz1xyvJFwJf| last=Vlessing| first=Etan| title=National Film Board puts final touches to "The Portrait"| date=5 June 2012| publisher=Realscreen| accessdate=16 June 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402171234/http://realscreen.com/2012/06/07/national-film-board-puts-final-touches-to-the-portrait/#ixzz1xyvJFwJf| archivedate=2 April 2015| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfb.ca/film/portrait/|title=The Portrait|last=Davis, Hubert (director)|work=Documentary film|publisher=[[National Film Board of Canada]]|accessdate=13 October 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017044641/http://www.nfb.ca/film/portrait|archivedate=17 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The painting was on 25 June installed in the ballroom at Rideau Hall. Dedicated at the same time by the Governor General were new bronze and glass handrails, with detailing evoking the Diamond Jubilee, flanking the ceremonial staircase in Rideau Hall's main entrance foyer.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14596| last=Office of the Governor General of Canada| title=Her Majesty The Queen's New Painting Arrives at Rideau Hall| date=25 June 2012| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=28 June 2012}}</ref>
On 12 June 2012, the government of the [[Northwest Territories]] (NWT) and the City of [[Yellowknife]] held at the Northern Arts and Cultural Centre a garden party with [[barbecue]], concert, and other activities. On 14 June, Amber Jubilee Ninebark shrubs were planted on the grounds of the NWT legislative assembly.<ref name=NWT /> Four days later, a gala concert was held at [[Roy Thomson Hall]] in Toronto, at which 600 diamond jubilee medals were awarded to members of the [[Order of Canada]] and [[Order of Ontario]]. The event, hosted by the Lieutenant Governor of Ontario, was attended by the Governor General and his wife and performers included the [[Famous People Players]], [[Susan Aglukark]], [[Molly Johnson]], [[Ben Heppner]], and [[Gordon Lightfoot]], who conceived the idea of the event.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2012/06/18/jubilee-gala-toronto.html| title=Diamond Jubilee Gala toasts exceptional Canadians| date=18 June 2012| publisher=CBC| accessdate=19 June 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120619053044/http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2012/06/18/jubilee-gala-toronto.html| archivedate=19 June 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Further events==== The [[Lieutenant Governor of Saskatchewan]] held a garden party at [[Government House (Saskatchewan)|Government House]] on [[Canada Day]] and,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://jubileesk.ca/events/item/?e=6| last=Government of Saskatchewan| title=Events > Garden Party| publisher=Queen's Printer for Saskatchewan| accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref> in the Northwest Territories, the Canada Day parade was themed to celebrate the jubilee and numerous jubilee medal presentation ceremonies took place.<ref name=NWT /> Also on 1 July, the [[Canadian Museum of Civilization]] opened the exhibit ''A Queen and Her Country'', showing artefacts from the [[Crown Collection]] relating to Queen Elizabeth II and her role as Queen of Canada, including the [[Queen's Beasts]] from [[Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II|her coronation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civilization.ca/exhibitions/special-exhibitions/a-queen-and-her-country3| title=Exhibitions > Special Exhibitions > A Queen and Her Country| publisher=Canadian Museum of Civilization| accessdate=28 June 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625031245/http://www.civilization.ca/exhibitions/special-exhibitions/a-queen-and-her-country3| archivedate=25 June 2012 }}</ref> At Rideau Hall on 11 September, a reception, attended by the Governor General; his wife; [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]]; [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex]]; and others, was held for the [[Royal Victorian Order]] Association of Canada and to "honour of the 60th anniversary of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II’s accession to the Throne."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14708| last=Office of the Governor General of Canada| title=Working Visit to Canada by The Earl and Countess of Wessex| date=10 September 2012| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=12 September 2012}}</ref> The Earl also distributed Diamond Jubilee Medals to recipients in Toronto and to members of the RCMP in [[Iqaluit]], [[Nunavut]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://blogs.canoe.ca/royalspectacle/general/prince-edward-sophie-kick-off-tour/| last=Schwass-Bueckert| first=Kate| title=Prince Edward, Sophie kick off tour| date=11 September 2012| publisher=Canoe| accessdate=16 September 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130115071634/http://blogs.canoe.ca/royalspectacle/general/prince-edward-sophie-kick-off-tour/| archivedate=15 January 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2012/09/13/north-royal-visit-iqaluit.html| title=Royals commend RCMP officers in Iqaluit| date=13 September 2012| publisher=CBC| accessdate=16 September 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120916015841/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2012/09/13/north-royal-visit-iqaluit.html| archivedate=16 September 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The government of the NWT held through September an essay contest for youth to explain "how the Queen is important to [[First Nations]] and [[Métis people (Canada)|Métis people]]."<ref name=NWT />

the Crown| publisher=Queen's Printer for Saskatchewan| accessdate=7 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120710034648/http://jubileesk.ca/events/item/?e=7| archivedate=10 July 2012| ===Jamaica=== [[Prince Harry]] toured Jamaica between 5 and 8 March 2012,<ref name=GoJam>{{cite news| url=http://go-jamaica.com/news/read_article.php?id=35102| title=Preparations underway for Prince’s visit| date=7 February 2012| publisher=Go-Jamaica| accessdate=11 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210183703/http://go-jamaica.com/news/read_article.php?id=35102| archivedate=10 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{citation| url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Big-foreign-media-coverage-for-Prince-Harry-s-visit_10924286| title=Big foreign media coverage for Prince Harry's visit| date=29 February 2012| newspaper=Jamaica Observer| accessdate=29 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302182553/http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/Big-foreign-media-coverage-for-Prince-Harry-s-visit_10924286| archivedate=2 March 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> participating in various events marking his grandmother's Diamond Jubilee as Jamaica's queen regnant, first as [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Queen of the United Kingdom]], between 1952 and 1962, and subsequently as [[Monarchy of Jamaica|Queen of Jamaica]] (Jamaica will also thus be concurrently celebrating 50 years of independence). During the tour, the Prince partook in military exercises with the [[Jamaica Defence Force]], visited Bustamante Hospital for Children and, in [[Trelawny Parish]], visited Water Square, Falmouth Pier, and the William Knibb Baptist Church, where he paid respect at the [[William Knibb]] memorial. The Prince attended an event for the charity Rise Life,<ref>{{citation| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2111338/Prince-Harry-Jamaica-Prince-dances-Bob-Marley-Diamond-Jubilee-tour-wearing-blue-shoes.html| title=Don't step on my blue suede shoes: Party Prince Harry gets down to Bob Marley in Jamaica wearing {{Sic|hide=y|brightly|-}}coloured desert boots| date=7 March 2012| newspaper=Daily Mail| accessdate=8 March 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308033052/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2111338/Prince-Harry-Jamaica-Prince-dances-Bob-Marley-Diamond-Jubilee-tour-wearing-blue-shoes.html| archivedate=8 March 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> ran with [[Usain Bolt]] at the latter's training ground at the [[University of the West Indies]], [[Mona, Jamaica|Mona]]. There, he was also named an Honorary Fellow of the university.<ref>{{citation| url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/latest/article.php?id=35727| title=Prince Harry named Honorary UWI Fellow| date=6 March 2012| newspaper=The Gleaner| accessdate=8 March 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307233703/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/latest/article.php?id=35727| archivedate=7 March 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> A Jamaica Night reception was held at the Royal Caribbean Hotel in Montego Bay and [[Governor-General of Jamaica]] Sir [[Patrick Allen (politician)|Patrick Allen]] hosted a dinner at [[King's House, Jamaica|King's House]] as a combined celebration of the Diamond Jubilee and Jamaica's 50th anniversary of independence. The Prime Minister, [[Portia Simpson Miller]], stated the tour was intended to "highlight the country's tourism developments on the North Coast and the important work being done in the area of youth and children."<ref name=GoJam />
The Governor-General and his wife travelled to London, United Kingdom (UK), to partake in various events there in June, including a reception held by the High Commissioner of Jamaica to the UK.<ref name=JGDJL /> Jamaica's Diamond Jubilee celebrations proceeded despite Miller's ongoing work to have the country become a republic.<ref>{{citation| url=http://www.jis.gov.jm/news/leads/30943| title=High Commissioner Assures UK Jamaicans on Republic Status| date=17 June 2012| publisher=Jamaica Information Service| accessdate=24 June 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525154011/http://www.jis.gov.jm/news/leads/30943| archivedate=25 May 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref>

archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207184309/http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU1202/S00036/waitangi-day-starts-queens-diamond-jubilee-celebrations.htm| archivedate=7 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The New Zealand post also issued sets of Diamond Jubilee stamps showing images of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip throughout her reign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stamps.nzpost.co.nz/new-zealand/2012/queen-elizabeth-ii-diamond-jubilee|title=2012 Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee|author=|date=|website=New Zealand Post Stamps|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222031115/http://stamps.nzpost.co.nz/new-zealand/2012/queen-elizabeth-ii-diamond-jubilee|archivedate=22 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Prime Minister [[John Key]] moved a motion in the [[New Zealand House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] congratulating the Queen on her Diamond Jubilee on 7 February.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.parliament.nz/en-NZ/PB/Debates/Debates/9/e/6/50HansD_20120207_00000012-Motions-Queen-Elizabeth-II-Diamond-Jubilee.htm| last=Parliament of New Zealand| authorlink=Parliament of New Zealand| title=Motions – Queen Elizabeth II – Diamond Jubilee| publisher=Government Printing Office| accessdate=10 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304173955/http://www.parliament.nz/en-NZ/PB/Debates/Debates/9/e/6/50HansD_20120207_00000012-Motions-Queen-Elizabeth-II-Diamond-Jubilee.htm| archivedate=4 March 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[Queen-in-Council|Governor-General-in-Council]] also launched, two days later, via the [[Ministry of Health (New Zealand)|Ministry of Health]], the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Research Grant, "seeking to purchase research projects that transfer knowledge from initiatives with proven effectiveness, into practice in the health sector".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.govt.nz/news-and-media/news/queen-elizabeth-ii-jubilee-research-grant-health-knowledge-action |last=Health Research Council of New Zealand |title=Queen Elizabeth II Jubilee Research Grant – Health Knowledge to Action |date=9 February 2012 |publisher=Government Printing Office |accessdate=19 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213030438/http://www.hrc.govt.nz/news-and-media/news/queen-elizabeth-ii-jubilee-research-grant-health-knowledge-action |archivedate=13 February 2012 }}</ref>
The New Zealand Army Band took part in the Diamond Jubilee Pageant held at Windsor Castle and also took part in the changing of guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace. In New Zealand, ''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' opinion columnist [[Jim Hopkins]] was critical of the jubilee celebrations held over the [[Queen's Birthday#New Zealand|Queen's Birthday weekend]], calling it a "missed opportunity".<ref name=hopkins>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/opinion/news/article.cfm?c_id=466&objectid=10811537|title=Shame we blew Queen's Jubilee|date=8 June 2012|accessdate=30 July 2012|publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]}}</ref> He was also critical of [[TVNZ]]'s lack of jubilee related content in its daily news broadcast.<ref name=hopkins />
A royal tour was undertaken by [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], and [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]], between 10 and 16 November 2012.<ref name=TelegraphPoW /><ref>{{cite press release| last=Office of the Prime Minister of New Zealand| title=PM marks beginning of Diamond Jubilee year| publisher=Government Printing Office| date=6 February 2012| url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1202/S00051/pm-marks-beginning-of-diamond-jubilee-year.htm| accessdate=6 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207145515/http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1202/S00051/pm-marks-beginning-of-diamond-jubilee-year.htm| archivedate=7 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> travelling to [[Auckland]], [[Wellington, New Zealand|Wellington]], [[Christchurch]], and [[Manawatu]]. Their programme is to focus on excellence and innovation in business, agriculture, community service, and sports, as well as children's literacy and animal health.<ref name=TelegraphPoW />
===Papua New Guinea=== [[Charles, Prince of Wales]], and [[Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall]], toured Papua New Guinea between 3 and 5 November. During their time in the country, the couple met church, charity, and community volunteers, cultural groups, and members of the [[Papua New Guinea Defence Force]] in and near [[Port Moresby]].<ref name=TelegraphPoW />
===Oceanic realms=== [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]], and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]], visited the [[Solomon Islands]] and [[Tuvalu]].<ref name=BBCJplans />
===Other Caribbean and West Indies realms=== The Queen's realms throughout the Caribbean and West Indies planned a number of Diamond Jubilee events. Using [[RFA Fort Rosalie (A385)|RFA ''Fort Rosalie'']], [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], and [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex]], visited other Caribbean realms, including: Antigua and Barbuda, Grenada, Montserrat and Saint Lucia.<ref name=BBCJplans /><ref>{{Citation|last=Prime Minister of St. Kitts and Nevis |title=Display during visit of cruise ship Queen Elizabeth to mark Diamond Jubilee |publisher=The Office of the Prime Minister of St. Kitts and Nevis |date=7 December 2011 |url=http://www.cuopm.com/newsitem_new.asp?articlenumber=2583&post200803=true |accessdate=8 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415034623/http://www.cuopm.com/newsitem_new.asp?articlenumber=2583&post200803=true |archivedate=15 April 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/the_queens_diamond_jubilee/8955439/Diamond-Jubilee-Royal-Family-will-visit-every-Realm.html| title=Diamond Jubilee: Royal Family will visit every Realm| author=Staff writer| date=14 December 2011| work=The Daily Telegraph| location=UK| at=| trans-title=| accessdate=5 February 2012| quote=| ref=| separator=| postscript=| dead-url=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210003539/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/the_queens_diamond_jubilee/8955439/Diamond-Jubilee-Royal-Family-will-visit-every-Realm.html| archivedate=10 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Saint Kitts and Nevis=== Historical re-enactments were put on in Saint Kitts and Nevis for the Earl and Countess of Wessex, who arrived on 3 March 2012.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sknvibes.com/news/newsdetails.cfm/53702| title=Dramatic historical re-enactments to mark Diamond Jubilee celebration| date=17 February 2012| publisher=SKNVibes| accessdate=19 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225031529/http://www.sknvibes.com/news/newsdetails.cfm/53702| archivedate=25 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> There, the couple met with Governor-General Sir [[Cuthbert Sebastian]], Prime Minister [[Denzil Douglas]], and other dignitaries, watched cultural shows (including the performance of a [[Calypso music|calypso]] song about the Queen), and the Earl unveiled a plaque commemorating the Diamond Jubilee and officially designated the [[Basseterre Valley]] Park as the Royal Basseterre Valley Park. They also visited [[Brimstone Hill Fortress National Park]] and the children's ward of the JNF Hospital and the Children's Home before attending a state dinner and fireworks display at Port Zante.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.winnfm.com/news2.asp?NewsID=8293#.T1JtfH2Hawc.twitter| last=Frederick| first=Toni|title=Prince Edward delights the crowd| date=3 March 2012| publisher=Winn FM| accessdate=6 March 2012}}{{dead link|date=August 2013}}</ref>
===Saint Lucia=== The Earl and Countess of Wessex arrived in Saint Lucia on 21 February 2012 and there participated in Independence Day celebrations and attended receptions held by the [[Governor-General of Saint Lucia]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nationnews.com/articles/view/st-lucia-celebrates-33-years-of-independence/| title=St Lucia celebrates 33 years of Independence| date=22 February 2012| publisher=NationNews| accessdate=23 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202222118/http://www.nationnews.com/articles/view/st-lucia-celebrates-33-years-of-independence/| archivedate=2 December 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref> They also visited the Association of Saint Lucia and the Saint Lucia School of Music.<ref>{{citation| url=http://www.thedominican.net/2012/02/royals-to-begin-visit.html| title=Royals to begin Caribbean tour bypasses Dominica| date=16 February 2012| newspaper=The Dominican| accessdate=19 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203072813/http://www.thedominican.net/2012/02/royals-to-begin-visit.html| archivedate=3 December 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Saint Vincent and the Grenadines=== In Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, a Diamond Jubilee Celebrations Committee was established to oversee events staged to mark, between February and June 2012, the Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II's accession as queen regnant of the country, from 1952 to 1979 as [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|Queen of the United Kingdom]] and thereafter as [[Monarchy of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|Queen of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]. The committee head, former Minister of Culture Rene Baptiste, stated the aim was to "showcase what we have to offer, as well as our loyalty to the Parliament..." The Earl and Countess of Wessex, aboard [[RFA Fort Rosalie (A385)|RFA ''Fort Rosalie'']], arrived for their tour of country on 25 February and visited the restored [[Botanic Gardens St. Vincent]] and planted a Pink Poui tree, attended an official lunch at Government House, and planted [[Roystonea|Royal Palms]] on the [[Grenadines]].
Trade unionist Noel Jackson said he heard displeasure expressed by Vincentians towards the royal tour and that "a lot of people were cursing." Senator Julian Francis, the General Secretary of the governing [[Unity Labour Party]], stated the public reaction to the presence of the royal couple "confirmed to me that we could not have won [[Vincentian constitutional referendum, 2009|the 2009 referendum on a republic]]. The outpouring of the people in St. Vincent to come and greet Prince Edward yesterday confirmed to me that people, in the majority in St. Vincent, still want the monarchy... It was like a carnival in town yesterday."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://i-witness-news.com/2012/02/27/majority-of-vincentians-still-want-the-monarchy/| title=Majority of Vincentians 'still want the monarchy'| date=27 February 2012| publisher=I-Witness News| accessdate=28 February 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301110030/http://i-witness-news.com/2012/02/27/majority-of-vincentians-still-want-the-monarchy/| archivedate=1 March 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
A Diamond Jubilee Lecture was delivered in March, a flower show and tea party was held at Government House on 4 and 5 May, a stamp exhibition was mounted at the National Trust headquarters and an exhibition of photographs of the Queen in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines was displayed at the National Public Library. A Queen's Birthday parade took place, as did a Diamond Jubilee Beacon Event on 4 June, part of the wider plan to light such beacons at the same time across the Commonwealth.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.thevincentian.com/dcmain.aspx?p=0&i=9355&skin=75&tID=198 |last=Clarke |first=Karissa |title=Big plans to mark Queen's Diamond Jubilee |date=2 February 2012 |newspaper=The Vincentian |accessdate=5 February 2012 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== [[File:Diamond Jubilee 60 2012 logo.jpg|thumb|right|The United Kingdom's Diamond Jubilee logo]] [[File:Cmglee Sea Containers House OXO Tower jubilee.jpg|thumb|right|[[Sea Containers House]] decorated with a [[Largest photographs in the world|large photograph]] of [[Silver Jubilee of Elizabeth II|her Silver Jubilee]]]] [[File:Red Arrows II.JPG|thumb|right|Flypast by the [[Red Arrows]] over Buckingham Palace on 5 June]]
====Planning==== In the United Kingdom, national and regional events to mark the Diamond Jubilee were coordinated by the [[Queen-in-Council]] and her Royal Household at [[Buckingham Palace]].<ref name=Mail>{{Cite news| title=The Queen: Don't link my Jubilee celebration to 'flashy' Olympics| work=Daily Mail| location=London| date=27 June 2009| url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1195973/The-Queen-Dont-link-Jubilee-celebration-flashy-Olympics.html| accessdate=31 October 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130114055826/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1195973/The-Queen-Dont-link-Jubilee-celebration-flashy-Olympics.html| archivedate=14 January 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref> As with the [[Golden Jubilee of Elizabeth II|Golden Jubilee]] in 2002, the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]] was responsible for coordinating the [[Cabinet of the United Kingdom|Cabinet]]-led aspects of the celebrations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gov.uk/what_we_do/honours/diamondjubilee.aspx| last=Department of Culture, Media, and Sport| title=diamond jubilee| publisher=[[Queen's Printer]]| accessdate=31 October 2010| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100927050301/http://culture.gov.uk/what_we_do/honours/diamondjubilee.aspx| archivedate=27 September 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gov.uk/diamondjubilee| last=Department for Culture, Media, and Sport| authorlink=Department for Culture, Media and Sport| title=what we do > honours and ceremonials > diamond jubilee| publisher=[[Queen's Printer]]| accessdate=20 April 2010| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329153058/http://www.culture.gov.uk/diamondjubilee| archivedate=29 March 2010 }}</ref> Events were planned so as to keep the use of tax money to a minimum; most funds used to fund celebrations were drawn from private donors and sponsors. Only the cost of security was by [[HM Treasury|Her Majesty's Treasury]].<ref name=GlobePomp /> The British logo for the Diamond Jubilee was selected through a contest held by the [[BBC]] children's programme ''[[Blue Peter]]''; the winning design, announced in February 2011, was created by ten-year-old Katherine Dewar.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12518165|title=Queen's Diamond Jubilee emblem revealed|date=21 February 2011|accessdate=21 February 2011|publisher=BBC News|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110221051419/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-12518165|archivedate=21 February 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Pressreleases/2011/DiamondJubileeemblemunveiled21February2011.aspx| last=Royal Household| title=Diamond Jubilee emblem unveiled| publisher=[[Queen's Printer]]| date=11 February 2011| accessdate=10 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215181939/http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Pressreleases/2011/DiamondJubileeemblemunveiled21February2011.aspx| archivedate=15 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Drupal]], a [[free and open-source software|free open-source]] [[content management system]], was used for the official website.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.computerminds.co.uk/drupal-projects| last=ComputerMinds| title=Drupal Portfolio – Diamond Jubilee website| publisher=ComputerMinds| date=3 November 2011| accessdate=2 June 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622003231/http://www.computerminds.co.uk/drupal-projects| archivedate=22 June 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Extended weekend==== On 5 January 2010, the [[Lord President of the Council]] and [[Secretary of State for Business, Innovation and Skills|Business Secretary]] [[Peter Mandelson|Lord Mandelson]] announced that an extra [[bank holiday]] would take place on 5 June 2012.<ref name=Mail /><ref name=PA>{{Cite news|title=Extra bank holiday to mark Jubilee |publisher=Press Association |date=5 January 2010 |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5iFc6Cmk-AJ72Mo5lMkmGuUqHSxIw |accessdate=5 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mYhY2Lxk?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5iFc6Cmk-AJ72Mo5lMkmGuUqHSxIw |archivedate=5 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name=BIS>{{cite web|title=Extra Bank holiday to mark Queen's Diamond Jubilee |publisher=Department for Business Innovation & Skills |date=5 January 2010 |url=http://www.bis.gov.uk/jubilee |accessdate=6 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5maXCgrOr?url=http://www.bis.gov.uk/jubilee |archivedate=6 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Moving the Spring Bank Holiday (the last Monday in May) to 4 June resulted in a four-day holiday in honour of the Diamond Jubilee.<ref name=PA /><ref name=Reuters>{{Cite news|title=Extra holiday for 2012 Jubilee |publisher=Reuters |date=5 January 2010 |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE6043L120100105 |accessdate=5 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mYhZFG8i?url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE6043L120100105 |archivedate=5 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> As national holidays are a [[Reserved and excepted matters|devolved matter]], Scotland's [[First Minister of Scotland|first minister]] confirmed that the bank holiday would be held on 5 June in Scotland. Some economists later theorised that the holiday could reduce the country's gross domestic product by 0.5% in the second quarter of the year, though this would be partially offset by increased sales for the hospitality and merchandise sectors.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.sky.com/home/business/article/16163892| title='Diamond Jubilee Could Harm The Economy'| publisher=Sky News| date=6 February 2012| accessdate=6 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207185203/http://news.sky.com/home/business/article/16163892| archivedate=7 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[File:Queen Elizabeth II.JPG|thumb|left|The Queen travelling by car to [[St Paul's Cathedral]] for the service of thanksgiving on 5 June]]
Many events were staged in London during the bank holiday weekend.<ref name=Reuters /> The [[River Thames|River]] [[Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant]] was held on 3 June; a maritime parade of 1,000 boats from around the Commonwealth—the largest flotilla seen on the river in 350 years—together with other celebrations along the river banks.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://thamesdiamondjubileepageant.org/| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407222350/http://www.thamesdiamondjubileepageant.org/| dead-url=yes| archive-date=7 April 2011| title=Welcome| publisher=Diamond Jubilee| accessdate=7 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=London river extravaganza planned for Queen's jubilee| publisher=France 24| date=6 April 2011| url=http://www.france24.com/en/20110406-london-river-extravaganza-planned-queens-jubilee| accessdate=7 April 2011| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126151433/http://www.france24.com/en/20110406-london-river-extravaganza-planned-queens-jubilee| archivedate=26 January 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation| last=Bates| first=Stephen| title=Thames flotilla to mark Queen's diamond jubilee| newspaper=The Guardian| date=5 April 2011| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/apr/05/thames-flotilla-queen-diamond-jubilee| accessdate=7 April 2011| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203051933/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/apr/05/thames-flotilla-queen-diamond-jubilee| archivedate=3 December 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref> Heavy rain started during the event and the commemorative airforce flyover at the end was cancelled due to very low [[cloud base]] and bad visibility at ground level. Along with almost all members of the Royal Family, various governors-general from the Commonwealth realms other than the UK were in attendance.<ref name=GGLondon>{{cite web| url=http://www.gg.ca/document.aspx?id=14556| last=Office of the Governor General of Canada| title=The Central Weekend – Queen's Diamond Jubilee| date=1 June 2012| publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada| accessdate=4 June 2012}}</ref><ref name=JGDJL>{{citation| url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20120601/social/social5.html| title=Sir Patrick and Lady Allen for Diamond Jubilee| date=1 June 2012| newspaper=Jamaica Gleaner| accessdate=4 June 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603040004/http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20120601/social/social5.html| archivedate=3 June 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[Diamond Jubilee Concert]], with a preceding afternoon picnic in the palace gardens for the 10,000 concert ticket holders,<ref name=BBC_McCartney_to_play>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16925230| title=Sir Paul McCartney to play Queen Diamond Jubilee gig| publisher=BBC| work=BBC News| date=7 February 2012| accessdate=20 April 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120519122700/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16925230| archivedate=19 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=BBC_Webber_Barlow>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17152327| title=Andrew Lloyd Webber and Gary Barlow write Jubilee song| publisher=BBC| work=BBC News| date=24 February 2012| accessdate=20 April 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418202717/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17152327| archivedate=18 April 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=BBC_Blumenthal>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17757416| title=Heston Blumenthal plans 'best of British' Jubilee picnic| publisher=BBC| work=BBC News| date=18 April 2012| accessdate=20 April 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419224021/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17757416| archivedate=19 April 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> was held the following day, in front of [[Buckingham Palace]], and featured acts representing each decade of the Queen's 60-year reign.
[[Street party|Street parties]] were permitted to take place across the country.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/newsstories/newsroom/1700319| last=Department for Communities and Local Government| title=The new, simple, easy-to-use form to organise street parties has arrived!| publisher=[[Queen's Printer]]| accessdate=19 February 2011| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202145525/http://www.communities.gov.uk/newsstories/newsroom/1700319| archivedate=2 February 2011| df=dmy-all}}</ref> Special community lottery grants, called ''The Jubilee People's Millions'', are being offered by the [[Big Lottery Fund]] and [[ITV plc|ITV]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peoplesmillions.org.uk/faqs|title=Lottery Millions to Help Communities Bloom for Diamond Jubilee|publisher=The National Lottery|accessdate=19 February 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305184121/http://www.peoplesmillions.org.uk/faqs|archivedate=5 March 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Members of the Royal Family, governors-general, and prime ministers from the Commonwealth realms were present at various functions held on 4 and 5 June: A reception took place at Buckingham Palace before the Diamond Jubilee Concert and a service of thanksgiving was conducted the following day at [[St Paul's Cathedral|St. Paul's Cathedral]], also attended by 2,000 other guests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stpauls.co.uk/News-Press/News-Archive/2012/Queen-celebrates-Jubilee-at-St-Pauls-images|title=Queen celebrates Jubilee at St Paul's|publisher=St Paul's Cathedral|accessdate=20 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Will Todd]]'s anthem "The Call of Wisdom", commissioned specially for this event, was performed by the Diamond Choir, made up of about 40 children from around the UK.<ref>{{cite web| title=OUP: Diamond Jubilee anthem by Will Todd| url=http://www.oup.com/uk/pressreleases/willtodd/| publisher=Oxford University Press| accessdate=3 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606130004/http://www.oup.com/uk/pressreleases/willtodd/| archivedate=6 June 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=Diamond Choir: Meet the Choir| url=http://www.diamondchoir.co.uk/meet-the-choir.asp| publisher=St. Paul's Cathedral| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130723171816/http://www.diamondchoir.co.uk/meet-the-choir.asp| archivedate=23 July 2013| df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[The Archbishop of Canterbury]] dedicated his sermon to the Queen, during which he noted her "lifelong dedication" and stated that she "has made her 'public' happy and all the signs are that she is herself happy, fulfilled and at home in these encounters."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18330637| title=Dr Williams pays tribute to the Queen at thanksgiving| date=5 June 2012| publisher=BBC| accessdate=24 June 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610205106/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18330637| archivedate=10 June 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> Afterwards, a formal lunch was held in [[Westminster Hall]]. The Queen returned to [[Buckingham Palace]] at 2:20 pm, in an open top carriage procession and escorted by [[The Household Cavalry Regiment]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18327711 Diamond jubilee: Flypast bring celebrations to an end] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608190912/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18327711 |date=8 June 2012 }} BBC News. Accessed 24 June 2012.</ref> Another reception was held at [[Guildhall, London|London's Guildhall]] and a luncheon took place at [[Lancaster House]], hosted by the British [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs]].<ref name=GlobePomp /><ref name=GGLondon /> A reception solely for governors-general was held by the Queen at Buckingham Palace.<ref name=GGLondon />
The weekend of celebrations ended with a balcony appearance at Buckingham Palace. The Queen appeared on the balcony with the Prince of Wales, the Duchess of Cornwall, the Duke of Cambridge, the Duchess of Cambridge, and Prince Harry in front of cheering crowds outside the palace and along [[The Mall, London|The Mall]]. There followed a [[feu de joie]] and a [[flypast]] by the [[Red Arrows]] and historic aircraft,<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18327711 Diamond Jubilee: flypast brings celebrations to an end] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608190912/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18327711 |date=8 June 2012 }} BBC News. Accessed 5 June 2012.</ref> including the last flying [[Lancaster bomber]] in Britain. Several media commentators commented on the significance of only senior members of the royal family appearing on the balcony. BBC royal correspondent Peter Hunt remarked that it "sent a message demonstrating both continuity and restraint at a time of austerity".<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18327711 Diamond Jubilee: flypast brings celebrations to an end] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608190912/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18327711 |date=8 June 2012 }} BBC News. Accessed 24 June 2012.</ref>
====Permanent tributes==== [[File:Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II Mosaic Picture by Helen Marshall, Towner Gallery.jpg|thumb|A mosaic picture of Elizabeth II in [[Towner Gallery]] in [[Eastbourne]]. The picture was produced by Helen Marshall for the diamond jubilee using more than 5,000 photos sent by the BBC viewers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-17516843|title=BBC South East Jubilee photo mosaic|author=|date=3 August 2012|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608151102/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-17516843|archivedate=8 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>]] To mark the jubilee, the Queen bestowed [[List of UK place names with royal patronage#Royal Borough|Royal Borough]] status on [[Royal Borough of Greenwich|Greenwich]], in southeast London.<ref name=PA /><ref name=GC>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenwich.gov.uk/Greenwich/LeisureCulture/RoyalGreenwich/RoyalGreenwich.htm |title=Greenwich to become Royal Borough |publisher=Greenwich Council |date=5 January 2010 |accessdate=5 January 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5mYjJHOZA?url=http://www.greenwich.gov.uk/Greenwich/LeisureCulture/RoyalGreenwich/RoyalGreenwich.htm |archivedate=5 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> In addition, a competition was held to grant in 2012 [[City status in the United Kingdom|city status]] to towns and either a [[List of lord mayoralties and lord provostships in the United Kingdom|lord mayoralty or lord provostship]] to one city.{{refn|The towns that bid for city status were:<ref name=entrants>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-13796689| title=More than 25 towns bid for Diamond Jubilee city status| publisher=BBC| date=16 June 2011| accessdate=18 June 2011| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617043606/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-13796689| archivedate=17 June 2011| df=dmy-all}}</ref> Bolton, Bournemouth, Chelmsford, Colchester, Coleraine, Corby, Craigavon, Croydon, Doncaster, Dorchester, Dudley, Dumfries, Gateshead, Goole, Luton, Medway, Middlesbrough, Milton Keynes, Perth, Reading, Southend, St Asaph, St Austell, Stockport, Tower Hamlets, and Wrexham.
The cities that bid for a Lord Mayoralty or Lord Provostship were:<ref name=entrants /> Armagh, Cambridge, Derby, Gloucester, Lancaster, Newport, Peterborough, Salford, Southampton, St Albans, Sunderland, and Wakefield.|group=n|name=Cities}}<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11887723|title=Diamond Jubilee to be marked by creation of new UK city|publisher=BBC|date=1 December 2010|accessdate=1 December 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101204074545/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11887723|archivedate=4 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> City status was awarded to [[Chelmsford]] in England, [[Perth, Scotland|Perth]] in Scotland and [[St Asaph]] in Wales. [[Armagh]], Northern Ireland, was awarded the Lord Mayoralty.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-17364651|title=Three towns win city status for Diamond Jubilee|publisher=BBC|date=14 March 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425183250/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-17364651|archivedate=25 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The Olympic park in East London, created for the [[2012 Summer Olympics|2012 London Olympics]], was named the [[Olympic Park, London|Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park]] following the Olympics.<ref>{{Cite news| title=Games site renamed the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park| publisher=BBC| date=7 October 2010| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-11492273| accessdate=15 October 2010| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101014074838/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-11492273| archivedate=14 October 2010| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Queen Elizabeth II Fields Challenge (Queen Elizabeth Fields Challenge in Scotland) was a project of the charity [[Fields in Trust]] to safeguard parks and green spaces as public recreation land in perpetuity for future generations to enjoy, and to provide a permanent legacy of the Diamond Jubilee and the Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.royalfoundation.com/our-work/queen-elizabeth-ii-fields-challenge/|title=Queen Elizabeth II Fields Challenge|publisher=The Royal Foundation|accessdate=24 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729104839/http://www.royalfoundation.com/our-work/queen-elizabeth-ii-fields-challenge/|archivedate=29 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[Woodland Trust]] planned to establish 60 Jubilee [[woodland]]s during 2011 and 2012, one of almost 500 acres – [[Flagship Diamond Wood]], Leicestershire – and the remainder 60 acres each.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14327232| title=Woodland Trust searching for jubilee wood site| publisher=BBC| date=30 July 2011| accessdate=30 July 2011| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110730171623/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14327232| archivedate=30 July 2011| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
A stained glass window, paid for by MPs and members of the House of Lords, was unveiled in the Queen's presence at [[Westminster Hall]] in March 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kennedy|first=Maev|title=Queen's diamond jubilee stained glass window unveiled by MPs|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/mar/20/queen-diamond-jubilee-glass|accessdate=5 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=20 March 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129203218/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/mar/20/queen-diamond-jubilee-glass|archivedate=29 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In addition, a majority of MPs endorsed the renaming of the [[clock tower]] of [[Westminster Palace]] that houses Big Ben, to the [[Elizabeth Tower]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Hough|first=Andrew|title=The Queen's Diamond Jubilee: 'Big Ben to be renamed Elizabeth Tower'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/the_queens_diamond_jubilee/9307060/The-Queens-Diamond-Jubilee-Big-Ben-to-be-renamed-Elizabeth-Tower.html|accessdate=3 June 2012|newspaper=Daily Telegraph|date=3 June 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603034658/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/the_queens_diamond_jubilee/9307060/The-Queens-Diamond-Jubilee-Big-Ben-to-be-renamed-Elizabeth-Tower.html|archivedate=3 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[File:RoyalJubileeBells in the church.jpg|thumb|The Royal Jubilee Bells in St James Garlickhythe before being hung in the church's tower]] The [[Royal Jubilee Bells]], made for the Jubilee and a feature of the [[Thames Diamond Jubilee Pageant]], were delivered to the church of [[St James Garlickhythe]] in the [[City of London]] on 15 June 2012 and arranged along the central aisle. They were dedicated by the [[John Waine|Rt Revd John Waine]] on Sunday 17 June and hanging commenced in the tower shortly thereafter. They were rung for the first time in the church on 4 July.<ref>{{cite web|last=Love|first=Dickon R.|url=http://london.lovesguide.com/james_garlickhythe.htm|title=Church Bells of the City of London - St James Garlickhythe|publisher=Love's Guide to the Bells of the City of London|accessdate=5 January 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170311191225/http://london.lovesguide.com/james_garlickhythe.htm|archivedate=11 March 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The Royal Mint issued a number of coins including an official £5 coin, a 5oz coin and a kilo coin.<ref>Sovereign Mint [http://sovereignmint.co.uk/queen-elizabeth-iis-diamond-jubilee-coins-issued-for-2012/ "Official Diamond Jubilee coins from the Royal Mint"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426173640/http://sovereignmint.co.uk/queen-elizabeth-iis-diamond-jubilee-coins-issued-for-2012/ |date=26 April 2015 }}, ''[[Official Diamond Jubilee coins from the Royal Mint]]''</ref> A five-pound [[sterling silver]] coin was issued by the Government of Gibraltar to mark the occasion.<ref>Towermint [http://www.towermint.com/Shop/product/27 "Diamond Jubilee Five Pounds Silver Coin"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805185313/http://www.towermint.com/Shop/product/27 |date=5 August 2012 }}, ''[[Diamond Jubilee Five Pounds Silver Coin]]'', 1 May 2012. Retrieved on 7 November 2012.</ref>
In October 2012 it was announced that the Queen would bestow the honorary title of [[Regius Professor]]ship to up to six university chairs in the United Kingdom, to recognise "excellence in teaching and research";<ref>{{Cite news| title=New Regius professorships to mark Jubilee| author=Elizabeth Gibney| url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/421475.article| magazine=Times Higher Education| date=12 October 2012| accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref> the number was chosen to represent the decades of the Queen's reign.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/80218/Entry-Guidelines-Q-A.pdf| format=PDF| title=Regius Professorships – entry guidelines| date=October 2012| publisher=[[Cabinet Office]]| accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref> The full list was announced on 29 January 2013 and comprised twelve new chairs, in recognition of the "exceptionally high quality" of the departments considered.<ref>{{Cite press release| title=Cabinet Office: The Queen awards prestigious Regius professorships to twelve universities| date=29 January 2013| publisher=PoliticsHome| url=http://www.politicshome.com/uk/article/70924/cabinet_office_the_queen_awards_prestigious_regius_professorships_to_twelve_universities.html| accessdate=3 April 2013| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322001916/http://www.politicshome.com/uk/article/70924/cabinet_office_the_queen_awards_prestigious_regius_professorships_to_twelve_universities.html| archivedate=22 March 2014| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew|Kew Gardens]] announced that the Main Gate, the entrance to the gardens from Kew Green, was to be renamed Elizabeth Gate in honour of the Queen. [[Princess Alexandra, The Honourable Lady Ogilvy|Princess Alexandra]] attended the naming ceremony on 21 October 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk/news/9993864.Royalty_opens_Kew_Gardens__Elizabeth_Gate/|title=Royalty opens Kew Gardens' Elizabeth Gate|work=Richmond and Twickenham Times|date=21 October 2012|accessdate=12 July 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714130113/http://www.richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk/news/9993864.Royalty_opens_Kew_Gardens__Elizabeth_Gate/|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 18 December 2012, the [[British Foreign Office]] announced that a portion of the British Antarctic Territory was to be named [[Queen Elizabeth Land]] in honour of Her Majesty in her diamond jubilee year.<ref>{{cite web|title=UK to name part of Antarctica Queen Elizabeth Land|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-20757382|work=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=18 December 2012|date=18 December 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DnEBpOVa?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-20757382|archivedate=19 January 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
A seemingly less permanent tribute that gained widespread popularity was a work provided by street artist [[Banksy]]. His [[Slave Labour (mural)|"Slave Labour"]] stencil on a north London wall offered pointed criticism of the jubilee celebrations and the conditions that support British nationalism.<ref>Sarah Lyall, {{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/01/world/europe/give-us-our-banksy-mural-back-londoners-say.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-02-26 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304110740/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/01/world/europe/give-us-our-banksy-mural-back-londoners-say.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 |archivedate=4 March 2013 |df=dmy-all }}, ''The New York Times'', 1 March 2013.</ref> The mural's removal and subsequent attempted sale at auction in February 2013 sparked international controversy, highlighting the piece's worth to local and regional residents.<ref>Richard Luscombe, {{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2013/feb/23/banksy-missing-mural-auction-stopped |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014183955/http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2013/feb/23/banksy-missing-mural-auction-stopped |archivedate=14 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}, ''The Guardian'', 23 February 2013</ref> Its title, perhaps coincidentally, conjured another contentious part of the celebrations where unemployed workers, bussed into London on an allegedly unpaid trial to staff security for the event, were made to work under what some described as "appalling" conditions.<ref>Felicity Morse, {{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/06/05/kerry-mccarthy-mp-jubilee-workfare-unemployed_n_1570067.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-03-28 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131209050000/http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/06/05/kerry-mccarthy-mp-jubilee-workfare-unemployed_n_1570067.html |archivedate=9 December 2013 |df=dmy-all }}, ''Huffington Post'', 5 June 2012.</ref>
====Other events==== On Accession Day, 6 February, a 62-[[21-gun salute|gun salute]] was mounted on the banks of the [[River Thames]], near the [[Tower of London]] and the Queen made a visit to [[Norfolk]], one of the first places the monarch visited after acceding to the throne.<ref name=BelStamps /> Later in the month, Queen Elizabeth attended a multi-faith (Bahá'í, Buddhist, Christian, Hindu, Jain, Jewish, Muslim, Sikh, and Zoroastrian) reception held at the residence of the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Lambeth Palace]], in honour of the jubilee.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.bahai.org/story/889| title=Queen launches Diamond Jubilee year with multifaith reception| date=21 February 2012| publisher=Bahá'í World News Service| accessdate=25 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120526103746/http://news.bahai.org/story/889| archivedate=26 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The Queen addressed both houses of [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|parliament]] in [[Westminster Hall]] on 20 March 2012.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16628608| title=Queen to address Parliament joint session for jubilee| publisher=BBC| date=19 January 2012| accessdate=19 February 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120223033218/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16628608| archivedate=23 February 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> Also in March, the [[Royal Commonwealth Society]] launched the Jubilee Time Capsule to mark the jubilee.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.jubileetimecapsule.org| title=Jubilee Time Capsule| publisher=Royal Commonwealth Society| accessdate=15 July 2011| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712104542/http://www.jubileetimecapsule.org/| archivedate=12 July 2011| df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]] and [[Andrew Marr]] created the television documentary ''[[The Diamond Queen (TV programme)|The Diamond Queen]]'', in which various members of the Royal Family and current and former politicians spoke about the Sovereign and her life. The documentary was criticised by the campaign group [[Republic (political organisation)|Republic]], which argued that it breached BBC guidelines on impartiality.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17119720 BBC royal series The Diamond Queen biased, Republic says] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527213129/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-17119720 |date=27 May 2012 }}, ''[[BBC News]]''</ref>
At Buckingham Palace, a display of the Queen's diamonds was opened to the public.<ref name=GlobePomp /> On 4 June, the bells in each of the 34 church bell towers along the [[River Welland]] valley rang in succession, ending with the ringing of the bell at [[Fosdyke]] 60 times.<ref>{{citation| url=http://www.northantset.co.uk/news/local/a-royal-ring-for-queen-s-jubilee-1-3814645#| title=A royal ring for Queen's jubilee| date=6 May 2012| newspaper=Evening Telegraph| accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref>
On 19 May, the Queen attended the [[Diamond Jubilee Armed Forces Parade and Muster]], the [[British Armed Forces]]' own tribute to the monarch, in [[Windsor Castle]] and nearby [[Home Park, Windsor|Home Park]]. The first time all three services had assembled for the Queen for such an event at the same time, it featured military reviews and a 2,500 strong military parade through the town, as well as a military flypast featuring 78 aircraft.<ref name=BBC_Parade>{{cite web| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18123991| title=Diamond Jubilee: Armed forces in parade and flypast| publisher=BBC| work=BBC News| date=19 May 2012| accessdate=19 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120519031218/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18123991| archivedate=19 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====Overseas territories==== [[File:Queen's Birthday Parade 2012 - Prince Edward.jpg|thumb|left|The Earl and Countess of Wessex at the Queen's Birthday Parade, Grand Casemates Square, [[Gibraltar]], June 2012]] [[Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester]], toured the [[British Virgin Islands]] (BVI) in March 2012. On [[Montserrat]], he met participants in the Sailability BVI programme, including [[Special Olympics]] medallists, and staff and associates of the Eslyn Henley Ritchie Learning Centre, BVI Technical and Vocational Institute, BVI Services, and the Department of Youth Affairs and Sports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ukinmontserrat.fco.gov.uk/en/news/?view=News&id=739827082 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120730041609/http://ukinmontserrat.fco.gov.uk/en/news/?view=News&id=739827082 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 July 2012 |last=Office of the Governor of Montserrat |authorlink=Governor of Montserrat |title=HRH The Duke of Gloucester Visits Watersports Centre, Inspects Sailability's Fleet |date=8 March 2012 |publisher=[[Queen's Printer]] |accessdate=8 March 2012 }}</ref>
[[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], and [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex]], visited the British Overseas Territory of [[Gibraltar]], between 11–13 June 2012,<ref name=TeleGibraltar>{{citation| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/spain/9258138/Spain-issues-formal-complaint-over-Prince-Edward-Gibraltar-visit.html| last=Govan| first=Fiona| title=Spain issues formal complaint over Prince Edward Gibraltar visit| date=10 May 2012| newspaper=The Telegraph| accessdate=11 May 2012| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511034927/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/spain/9258138/Spain-issues-formal-complaint-over-Prince-Edward-Gibraltar-visit.html| archivedate=11 May 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> and [[Montserrat]].{{When|date=March 2012}}<ref name=BBCJplans /> The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (Spain)|Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation]] expressed "upset and concern" about the couple's tour of Gibraltar, which Spain claims as Spanish territory.<ref name=TeleGibraltar />
==Other Commonwealth countries== Visits were planned by [[Anne, Princess Royal|Princess Anne]] to Zambia and Mozambique, while the [[Prince Richard, Duke of Gloucester|Duke of Gloucester]] made official visits to Uganda and Malta. In Asia, [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York]], visited India, while [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge]], and [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]], visited Malaysia, Singapore, and the Solomon Islands.<ref>{{Citation| last=guardian.co.uk| title=Royal family to mark Queen's diamond jubilee with visits to Commonwealth| newspaper=The Guardian| date=14 December 2011| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/dec/14/royal-family-diamond-jubilee-commonwealth| accessdate=15 December 2011| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140317185818/http://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/dec/14/royal-family-diamond-jubilee-commonwealth| archivedate=17 March 2014| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]], and [[Sophie, Countess of Wessex]], visited Trinidad and Tobago,<ref>{{cite news|last=Harris|first=Carolyn|title=Royals of the Caribbean: The 2012 Diamond Jubilee Commonwealth Tours Begin|url=http://www.royalhistorian.com/royals-of-the-caribbean-the-2012-diamond-jubilee-commonwealth-tours-begin/|accessdate=22 June 2013|publisher=royalhistorian.com|date=15 February 2012}}</ref> as did [[Governor General of Canada]] [[David Johnston]].
===South Africa=== The British Consulate in Cape Town,<ref>UK High Commission Pretoria{{vague|date=June 2012}}</ref> in conjunction with the Hout Bay and Llandudno Heritage Trust, hosted a firing of ancient muzzle-loading cannons at East Fort in Hout Bay. The Hout Bay and Llandudno Heritage Trust restored the Fort's original Swedish made 18 pounder muzzle-loading cannons, dating from 1752, and fired two rolling salvo salutes, of six cannon shots each, in the Queen’s honour and in recognition of the bond of friendship between South Africa and Great Britain. The South African Navy Band was in attendance and the guns were fired by VIPs who were guided by gunners of the "Honourable Order of Hout Bay Artillerymen".
At the Victoria and Alfred Waterfront of the Port of Cape Town, a flotilla from the [[Royal Cape Yacht Club]] sailed past the Hildebrand Ristorante and into-the Victoria Basin and the Cape Town Highlanders marched from Ferryman's to Nobel Square. British Consul General Chris Trott lit a beacon, followed by a further six-gun salute and both South African national anthem and "God Save the Queen", to mark the 60 years of Queen Elizabeth II's service to her people and the people of the world.
==Other countries==
===Hong Kong=== Hong Kong, a [[British overseas territory|British dependent territory]] until 1997 and the most populous one, had The Big Jubilee Lunch on 3 June 2012, organised by the [[Royal Commonwealth Society|Royal Commonwealth Society in Hong Kong]]. On 5 June 2012, there was a service of thanksgiving at the territory's [[Hong Kong Sheng Kung Hui|Anglican]] [[St. John's Cathedral (Hong Kong)|Cathedral Church of St. John the Evangelist]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ukinhongkong.fco.gov.uk/en/visiting-uk/jubilee-2012/hk-events |archive-url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20121214012754/http://ukinhongkong.fco.gov.uk/en/visiting-uk/jubilee-2012/hk-events |dead-url=yes |archive-date=14 December 2012 |title=Hong Kong Jubilee 2012 Events |publisher=UK in Hong Kong |date= |accessdate=6 June 2012 }}</ref>
